qas.question: What was ASCII inteded to be?

answers.text: one of several national variants of an international character code standard

qas.question: When was ISO's first acceptance of an international recommendation?
What was causing the confusion and incompatibility of the code points?

answers.text: ASCII's choices for the national use characters to seem to be de facto standards for the world

qas.question: When was ISO's last acceptance at an international recommendation?

plausible_answers.text: ASCII's choices for the national use characters to seem to be de facto standards for the world

qas.question: What was causing the confusion and incompatibility of the shared characters?
What were code points ultimately published as?

plausible_answers.text: once other countries did begin to make their own assignments

qas.question: When did the publication's choices cause confusion and incompatibility?
What shared no characters in common?

context: From early in its development, ASCII was intended to be just <a1_0>one of several national variants of an international character code standard<a1_0/>, ultimately published as <b6_0><b8_0>ISO/IEC 646 (<a0_0>1972<a0_0/>)<b8_0/><b6_0/>, which would share most characters in common but assign other locally useful characters to several code points reserved for "national use." However, the four years that elapsed between the publication of ASCII-1963 and ISO's first acceptance of an international recommendation during <a2_0><b4_0>1967<b4_0/><a2_0/> caused <a3_0><b5_0>ASCII's choices for the national use characters to seem to be de facto standards for the world<b5_0/><a3_0/>, causing confusion and incompatibility <b7_0>once other countries did begin to make their own assignments<b7_0/> to these code points.
